Award.AwardTitle: RCN-SEES: Building a Research Network for Promoting Arctic Urban Sustainability in Russia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a Research Coordination Network aimed at creating models for Arctic urban sustainability. It is a multi-disciplinary, international effort examining the interconnections among resource development, climate change, and evolving demographic patterns in an effort to provide advice to U.S., Russian, and other policy-makers on how to develop Arctic oil and natural gas deposits and their related infrastructure in a way that produces minimal impact on the environment. The five-year project will convene an annual meeting of scientists working on these issues in Washington and Russia (alternating yearly) in order to facilitate collaboration across disciplines and institutes and to spur better communication between the researchers and policy-making community. Between meetings, the network will engage its participants through webinars hosted at George Washington University, place-based exercises to develop recommendations for specific cities, and coordinating on-going research projects. Russia is the central focus of this project because its territory holds most of the Arctic's energy resources and is the site of the most extensive urban development in the high north. How Russia develops its Arctic energy resources and how its northern cities evolve over the next several decades will have a major impact on the environmental health of the entire Arctic region. The output of the project will be policy advice on how to improve Arctic sustainability in the crucial urban areas associated with energy resource development.

The project bridges disciplinary and national divides by bringing together geographers, political scientists, and sociologists to study the interaction of human and natural systems in the Arctic. Project personnel include researchers with a wide range of expertise, including knowledge of energy resource development; migration and employment patterns in Eurasia; and scientific measurement of permafrost thickness throughout Arctic regions. The project will provide additional enrichment for a) the graduate students and early career scholars who are involved in the networking activities, b) residents of Arctic urban developments who will receive area-specific advice on improving sustainability, c) and policy-makers who benefit from input on how infrastructure sites, resource exploitation, and social urban environments can be made more robust in light of forthcoming climate and socio-economic changes. Additionally, the project will serve underrepresented groups by assessing urban impacts on the indigenous peoples of the Arctic and examining the role that foreign laborers play in Arctic infrastructure development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RCN-SEES: Building a Research Network for Promoting Arctic Urban Sustainability in Russia made it possible to build a multi-national, multidisciplinary team of scientists to examine how energy production, climate change, and migration affect Arctic cities. Over six years, the project brought together approximately 50 faculty members from a wide variety of U.S. and international institutions for networking meetings in Washington, St. Petersburg, Murmansk, Helsinki, and Anchorage. In addition to the faculty members, five graduate students and six undergrads participated in the sessions and gained experience in helping to organize large-scale scientific conferences.

The project team members produced three books during the project period: Sustaining Russia's Arctic Cities: Resource Politics, Migration, and Climate Change; New Mobilities and Social Changes in Russia's Arctic Regions; and Urban Sustainability in the Arctic: Visions, Contexts and Challenges. Additionally, project papers and information were available on a website. Local policy makers participated in project events in both Russia and Alaska and project participants used their professional channels to provide advice to relevant policy makers. 

Intellectually, the project advanced the field of Arctic Studies by focusing greater attention on the cities in the Arctic. The vast majority of the Arctic population lives in cities, but little scienctific attention has been directed to these cities in the past. Increasing an urban focus in Arctic studies meets the goals laid out by the United States Arctic Reserach Commission for 2015-2018 and academic bodies, such as the International Arctic Science Committee's Third International Congress on Artic Research Planning. 

The project made an intellectual contribution to the field by starting a process to identify key indicators to measure urban sustainability in Arctic conditions. These indicators help Arctic communities to define concrete goals and measure progress toward achieving them.

In terms of broader social impact, this research coordination network led to a new project whose goal is to develop an Arctic Urban Sustainability Index. This index will allow Arctic mayors to track the progress of their cities toward sustainabiity goals and alert them to areas where more resources are needed. Additionally, the Index will allow them to compare their cities with other Arctic cities and identify best practices from elsewhere that can be implemented at home. 

The project also helped to develop new techniques for digital story-telling as a way to stimulate interest in STEM fields among K-12 students. The efforts, growing in part out of this RCN, involve K-12 students in producing a series of 60 second videos which discuss local urban sustainability solutions, and then sharing them with other Arctic classrooms and DC are school students.
